Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: An open class is scheduled at the school, and the step-parent should attend
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Story:
I stared at the calendar on my phone, the bright red circle around “Open Class – 2:00 PM” glaring at me. My stepson, Jamie, had been talking about it for weeks, his eyes lighting up every time he asked if I’d be there. I promised I would. But just as I was about to leave for the school, my work phone buzzed. The factory’s operator was on the line again, his voice tense. He’d been struggling with the new press, and every time he tried to adjust the settings, he made things worse—wasting material, racking up costs. My supervisor’s message was clear: “You need to guide him, now. We can’t afford more mistakes.”

I felt the pressure building in my chest. Jamie was counting on me to show up, to prove I cared. But the operator was waiting, and if I didn’t help, the company would lose even more money—and my reputation as a reliable repairer would take a hit. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between the classroom and the factory floor, wishing I could split myself in two.
